headline: CORN SLIPS, WHEAT RALLIES, CATTLE SURGE
subheadline: Mixed grain action overnight as wheat strength and live cattle gains offset corn and bean weakness.
lead: Front-month corn dropped 1.13% to 438.75 while Chicago wheat jumped 2.51% to 591.25 — the spread is widening fast. Live cattle surged nearly 3% to 244.0, giving feedlot operators a reason to smile heading into March. Soybean meal took a 2.05% hit, pressuring crush margins and bean demand prospects.
teaser: Wheat and cattle surge while corn and meal slide — here's what to watch this week.

one_number.context: Wheat's sharp rally widens the corn-wheat spread, potentially shifting feed demand dynamics.

sections.title: GRAINS & OILSEEDS
sections.body: Corn front-month fell 1.13% to 438.75, but Dec '26 corn edged up 0.43% to 469.5 — the market is pricing in new-crop optimism. Soybeans slid 0.71% to 1157.25 with Nov '26 flat at 1128.25. Soybean meal dropped 2.05% to 315.5, putting pressure on crush economics. Wheat was the standout, rallying 2.51% to 591.25 — watch whether that strength spills into corn or simply reflects its own supply concerns.

sections.title: WEATHER & FIELD CONDITIONS
sections.body: Central Illinois sits at 27°F this morning with a high of 40°F expected, staying dry with only a 9% precip chance. Three-day precipitation totals just 0.32 inches — ground conditions remain firm. Early March looks manageable for fieldwork prep, but overnight lows in the low 20s mean no rush on soil temps. Wind at 16 mph could accelerate topsoil drying where frost is coming out.

sections.title: MARKETS & MACRO
sections.body: Live cattle jumped 2.96% to 244.0, a strong signal for beef demand and packer margins — feeders dipped 0.94% to 355.42. Crude oil rallied 2.62% to 67.02, which lifts input costs and supports ethanol margins. The dollar index slipped slightly to 97.565 and the 10-year fell to 3.962%, keeping borrowing costs manageable for now. S&P 500 off 0.43% — risk-off mood but nothing dramatic.

watch_list.desc: Markets closed Sunday — use downtime to review Commodity Classic announcements and tech updates.
USDA weekly export inspections (Monday) and any Crop Progress resumption as March begins.
Soybean meal weakness could drag bean prices lower if crush margins continue to deteriorate.
New-crop corn (Dec '26) showing resilience at 469.5 — consider pricing if rally extends.
